text.*:
For a broader coverage of this topic, see Universities and Higher Education in Brazil.

Universities in Brazil are ranked in a number of ways, including both national and international ranks.

Contents

  • 1 National Rankings
    • 1.1 Ranking Universitário Folha
    • 1.2 Brazilian government evaluation
      • 1.2.1 2012 Índice Geral de Cursos
  • 2 World rankings
    • 2.1 2013 Academic Ranking of World Universities [5]
    • 2.2 2013 QS World University Rankings
    • 2.3 2011-2012 Times Higher Education World University Rankings
  • 3 See also
  • 4 References
  • 5 External links

National Rankings[edit]

Ranking Universitário Folha[edit]

Brazil's largest newspaper Folha de S. Paulo organizes, since 2012, a national ranking of universities[1] with criteria akin to those used by the better known worldwide rankings: research, teaching, internationalization, innovation and market value.

2016[2] 2015[3] University
1 2 UFRJ - Federal University of Rio de Janeiro
2 1 USP - University of São Paulo
3 4 Unicamp - University of Campinas
4 3 UFMG - Federal University of Minas Gerais
5 5 UFRGS - Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul
6 6 Unesp - São Paulo State University
7 8 UFPR - Federal University of Paraná
8 7 UFSC - Federal University of Santa Catarina
9 9 UnB - University of Brasília
10 11 UFC - Federal University of Ceará
11 12 UFSCar - Federal University of São Carlos
12 10 UFPE - Federal University of Pernambuco
13 14 UERJ - Rio de Janeiro State University
14* 15 UFBA - Federal University of Bahia
14* 13 UFF - Fluminense Federal University
16 22 UNIFESP - Federal University of São Paulo
17 16 UFV - Federal University of Viçosa
18 18 UFSM - Federal University of Santa Maria
19 20* UFJF - Federal University of Juiz de Fora
20 17 UFG - Federal University of Goiás

* tied.

Brazilian government evaluation[edit]

This article may be expanded with text translated from the corresponding article in Portuguese. (October 2014) Click [show] for important translation instructions.
  • View a machine-translated version of the Portuguese article.
  • Google's machine translation is a useful starting point for translations, but translators must revise errors as necessary and confirm that the translation is accurate, rather than simply copy-pasting machine-translated text into the English Wikipedia.
  • Do not translate text that appears unreliable or low-quality. If possible, verify the text with references provided in the foreign-language article.

A model attribution edit summary (using German): Content in this edit is translated from the existing German Wikipedia article at [[:de:Exact name of German article]]; see its history for attribution.
  • You should also add the template {{Translated|pt|Anexo:Rankings de instituições de ensino superior brasileiras#Ranking de acordo com o Índice Geral de Cursos (IGC)}} to the talk page.
  • For more guidance, see Wikipedia:Translation.
This section's factual accuracy may be compromised due to out-of-date information. Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. (October 2014)

Higher education evaluations are also conducted by the Brazilian Government; specifically by Inep (Instituto Nacional de Estudos e Pesquisas Educacionais; English: National Institute of Studies and Research). The Government uses a General Index of Courses (Portuguese: Índice Geral de Cursos; IGC) to determinate the quality of Brazilian's higher education (graduate and post-graduate courses) in Brazil. It's important to add that Universidade de São Paulo, one of the most prestigious universities in the country, has been participating in the IGC since 2013 as part of a technical cooperation with Inep that will last three years, during which time the results concerning the university's courses will not be disclosed. Only then will the university decide whether to fully participate in the government evaluation.[1]
